newsitem.title: UK: Robert Bosch says to hike Dancall capacity. [CORRECTED 17:36 GMT]
newsitem.headline: Robert Bosch says to hike Dancall capacity. [CORRECTED 17:36 GMT]

text.p: German electronics group Robert Bosch GmbH said on Tuesday it would retain the entire workforce of Dancall Telecom and would increase its plant capacity to over two million units a year after it completes its purchase from British consumer electronics group Amstrad Plc.
Robert Bosch GmbH announced on Tuesday that it was buying Dancall from Amstrad Plc for 92 million pounds ($150.9 million).
"The management of Dancall will remain the same," Andreas Nobis, board member of Bosch Telecom told Reuters.
Dancall, with more than 600 employees, manufactures digital mobile telephones for use with GSM and PCN networks.
"We will continue with all the research, and there will be no redundancies," Nobis said.
The acquistion will mark Bosch Telecom's entry into the GSM market as its main business has been digital enhanced cordless telephones (DECT).
"We had decided to have our own production (in GSM) so a well-established set-up makes much sense to us," he said while explaining Bosch's strategy on Dancall.
Dancall's current capacity is 600,000 phone units per annum and Nobis said it would go up more than two million "as early as possible".
Nobis said Bosch would make investments in the Danish firm but gave no estimates.
Dancall's managing director will become a member of the management team of the Terminal Division of Bosch Telecom. (Corrects to show that the Dancall MD will serve in the Bosch management team).

Dancall Telecom was previously called Dancall Radio A/S until it ran into financial problems in the late 1980s. Amstrad acquired its assets, mainly the inventory and goodwill, from its receivers in September 1993 through a new company Dancall Telecom 6.3 million stg.
Nobis said it Dancall's main weakness has been its inability to achieve sufficient volumes.

Bosch will allow Dancall to retain its brand name on its phones where the 'Dancall' brand is popular like Denmark and other Scandanavian countries, but would be using the 'Bosch' name in other markets, Nobis said.
